title.narrative: Promoting city-wide inclusive sanitation through the Climate Resilience and Green Growth agenda (Senegal)

description.narrative:
During this Phase I, the project will focus on three main workstreams: policy, investment and knowledge sharing.
· In the policy workstream, GGGI foresees four outputs (Output 1, 2, 3 and 4): (1) to secure government commitment and endorsement to undertake policy interventions that help to create an enabling environment to attract finance for city-wide inclusive sanitation, (2) to secure endorsement for the implementation plan for one policy intervention by 12 months. GGGI will continue to support implementation or adoption in the 24 months, (3) to incorporate/embed sanitation in national plans/strategies for climate change, green growth and urban planning, and 4) to develop municipal green growth plans/strategies for each of the municipalities where the sanitation service is selected.
· In the project workstream, GGGI foresees one output (Output 5): (5) two investment projects for city-wide inclusive sanitation in the target cities, Kolda and Kaolack, for which investment commitment has been secured.
· In the knowledge-sharing workstream, GGGI foresees two outputs (Output 6 &7): (6) a strategy developed to mainstream CWIS in other GGGI partner countries based on lessons learnt and (7) to develop sanitation-specific metrics that allow for building a strong business case for sanitation
The goal of this project is to develop climate-resilient, pro-poor and sustainable city-wide inclusive sanitation (CWIS) services.

mailing-address.narrative: Global Green Growth Institute, 19F Jeongdong Bldg., 21-15 Jeongdong-gil, Jung-gu Seoul 04557 Republic of Korea

title.narrative: “Sanitation policies are mainstreamed with climate change and green growth national agendas.

The Omni processor's suitability is assessed to obtain financing from a range of climate funds and facilities, in accordance with their specific eligibility and results area requirements using data from Senegal, India and China

The technology (reinvented the toilets and any innovative sanitation technologies) suitability is assessed to obtain financing from a range of climate funds and facilities, in accordance with their specific eligibility and results area requirements using data from the technology and commercial partners.

Global Communications materials are developed on the linkages between sanitation and climate using work around the NDC in Senegal and the arguments are prepared for the GCF funding.
At least 4 presentations made at the key international and local events
SN06-7: Mainstreaming Strategy. (Strategy developed for mainstreaming CWIS in other GGGI partner countries based on lessons learnt.)
At least 2 sharing activities of the sanitation metrics to be used in NDCs or other National strategies held

title.narrative: Project Kick off meeting
Sanitation service delivery in secondary cities in Senegal is improved through climate finance and private investment.

description.narrative: Policies adopted by the GoS to improve the enabling environment for investment - Sanitation policies mainstreamed within green growth and climate national agenda. - Commitment letters of private/public investors - PPP contract signed for investments - The CWIS concept is shared and other cities have shown interest in adopting it.

Outcome 3: mainstreaming strategy and knowledge sharing platform are established for implementation of sustainable CWIS in other GGGI partner countries

Extent to which GGGI’s capacity development activities have directly strengthened partner countries capacity to develop and implement green growth policies and investments. To be assessed on a 5-point scale balanced scorecard with a maximum score of 10
